By Brendan O'Brien
| MILWAUKEE
MILWAUKEE U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan handily won a primary election for his congressional seat on Tuesday
column2: a contest overshadowed by presidential candidate Donald Trump's brief refusal last week to endorse his fellow Republican. Ryan
column3: who ran unsuccessfully for vice president in 2012
column4: had roughly 84 percent of the vote compared with challenger Paul Nehlen's 16 percent
column5: with 87 percent of voting areas reporting results
column6: the Journal Sentinel reported at 11 p.m. local time. ""I am humbled and honored that Wisconsinites in the 1st Congressional District support my efforts to keep fighting on their behalf
column7: Ryan said in a statement.In the general election for the 1st Congressional District seat in southeast Wisconsin on Nov. 8
column8: he will likely face Iraq war veteran Ryan Solen
column9: who won the Democrat primary on Tuesday.

column1: Nehlen thanked his supporters in a brief Twitter post after the polls closed.""Truly an amazing journey
column2: he said. The race became the center of attention a week ago when Trump refused to endorse Ryan during an interview with the Washington Post.

column1: In a sign of the tension between the politicians
column2: Trump told the newspaper he was ""not quite there yet"" - echoing a phrase Ryan had used about Trump. On Friday
column3: Trump endorsed Ryan and Senators John McCain of Arizona and Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire during a campaign stop in Green Bay
column4: a show of support that could be a step to mend his frayed relations with fellow Republicans.

column1: Trump
column3: has troubled many in the Republican establishment with his off-the-cuff
column4: often insulting
column5: style and controversial policies. These include a proposed ban on Muslims visiting the United States and his plan to build a wall along the Mexican border to keep out undocumented immigrants.Ryan
column6: Ayotte and McCain had criticized Trump's feud with the family of Army Captain Humayun Khan
column7: who was killed in Iraq in 2004 and was posthumously awarded the Bronze Star Medal for bravery. Trump had a running dispute with Khan's parents after they criticized him at last month's Democratic National Convention. (Reporting by Brendan O'Brien in Milwaukee; Additional reporting by Eric M. Johnson in Seattle; Editing by Paul Tait and Richard Pullin)"	['Ayotte'

WASHINGTON U.S. Vice President Joe Biden will visit Serbia and Kosovo next week

column4: Cuba
column5: to Serbia. U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry thanked Serbia for what he called a ""significant humanitarian gesture.""

column1: Kerry visited Serbia and Kosovo in December. His stop in Kosovo underscored Western concern over the slow pace of progress 16 years after a U.S.-led NATO air war set the former Serbian province on the road to independence.
Kosovo

2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-flake-idUSKCN10K2DI	Senator Flake: Trump can't win if he can't change	"
By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. Senator Jeff Flake said on Tuesday that Republican nominee Donald Trump will not be able to win the presidential election
column3: if he maintains the positions that he holds now
column4: including his harsh stance on immigration.In an interview
column5: Flake said he still hopes Trump will change enough that the Republican senator from Arizona will be able to vote for the candidate in the Nov. 8 election.But
column6: Flake said
column7: ""It's a slim hope.""He said that as things stand
column8: Trump will even have difficulty clinching the state of Arizona if the nominee
column9: who has called for building a wall on the border with Mexico
column10: does not develop a more ""serious"" immigration policy.Arizona last voted for a Democratic presidential candidate two decades ago.""Given the positions that he's taken
column11: if he continues to maintain those positions
column12: if he continues to hold to the statements he has made
column13: I don't think he can win the presidency
column14: nor do I think he should if he is unwilling to change

column1: There is a big difference between winning a primary
column3: 14 million votes
column4: and getting 65 million votes that you're going to need to win the presidency. In between those two numbers you encounter a number of swing voters
column5: independents
column6: who simply don't cotton to the kind of message that he has been delivering. And that's just the reality
column7: Flake said.Flake
column9: has long been one of Trump's more vocal critics on Capitol Hill. Trump's inflammatory remarks about immigrants have been a particular problem for Flake
column10: whose Southwestern border state has a large Hispanic population. Flake was among eight senators who proposed comprehensive immigration reform in 2013.Flake memorably told a reporter last month that he would not be attending the Republican convention to nominate Trump because he had to mow the lawn.

column1: Flake told Vanity Fair magazine in July: ""I don't think that there's much worry of a Trump presidency if he doesn't change.""But he also insists that he will not vote for the Democratic candidate
column2: former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.Flake
column3: a member of the House of Representatives for 12 years before being elected to the Senate in 2012
column4: said Arizonans are more realistic and pragmatic on immigration than Trump.

column1: Right now
column3: Arizona is almost a ""toss-up"" in the presidential election.Flake does not have to run for re-election to the Senate until 2018. His fellow Arizona senator
column4: John McCain
column5: is up for re-election this year
column6: and faces both primary and general election challengers. McCain has said he backs Trump.Flake said he respected Senator Susan Collins of Maine
column7: another Republican
column8: who said in an opinion article published on Monday that she definitely would not vote for Trump. Flake said he was not prepared to follow Collins' example
column9: which did not set off a stampede of Trump repudiations. (Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Jonathan Oatis)"	['McCain'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-advertising-idUSKCN10K2AD	Trump underspends Clinton on TV ads

Republican Donald Trump
column3: has yet to spend a dime on television advertising for his White House campaign against Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column4: who has spent $52 million

column9: it said.One group supporting Trump - the Rebuilding America Now PAC led by Florida Governor Rick Scott - said it was rolling out an anti-Clinton ad on cable and local television stations in Ohio

column1: While the New York businessman has not bought ads on ABC

4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-puertorico-debt-idUSKCN10K2A7	Puerto Rico readies fiscal plan
By Daniel Bases
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Puerto Rico's governor said on Tuesday he expected to present an updated fiscal plan for the debt-laden U.S. territory shortly after the White House appoints members of a federal oversight board with authority to renegotiate its $70 billion of debt.""I expect this new fiscal plan will be ready once the board is announced
column2: Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla told reporters in New York via a Skype video conference call from his office in San Juan. The call was part of an event organized by the City University of New York Graduate School of Journalism.On June 30th
column3: U.S. President Barack Obama signed the Puerto Rico Oversight
column4: Management and Economic Stability Act just one day before the island faced a deadline to make a debt payment of around $2 billion. Garcia Padilla authorized a suspension of the payments just after Obama signed the bill into law. Under the act
column5: the deadline for naming the seven-member board is Sept. 15. Garcia Padilla said on Tuesday he did not have any idea who would be named nor the timing
column6: but hoped it would happen before the end of August. Obama will choose from candidates presented by Republican and Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives and Senate.

column1: Garcia Padilla
column2: who is not running for reelection and has said the board would be an imposition on the island's sovereignty
column3: accepted that the legislation was needed in order to work out a solution.The oversight board has the authority to enforce balanced budgets and government reform if the Puerto Rican government fails to do so
column4: including the sale of government assets
column5: the consolidation of agencies and staff cuts.

column1: The board also has the authority to facilitate consensual restructuring talks
column2: or push Puerto Rico into a court-supervised process akin to U.S. bankruptcy.After years of talks between the government and its creditors
column3: failure to reach an agreement on restructuring the debt led to the passage of the legislation that all parties said was imperfect but necessary.

column1: Garcia Padilla said he was still open to talking with creditors and that ""prosperity will not return overnight."" (Reporting by Daniel Bases; Editing by Richard Chang)"	['Obama']	[]

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-qanda-factbox-idUSKCN10F2HK	Factbox: Why the Zika virus is causing alarm	"

Global health officials are racing to better understand the Zika virus behind a major outbreak that began in Brazil last year and has spread to many countries in the Americas. The following are some questions and answers about the virus and current outbreak:How do people become infected?Zika is transmitted to people through the bite of infected female mosquitoes
column3: the same type that spreads dengue
column4: chikungunya and yellow fever. The Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) said Aedes mosquitoes are found in all countries in the Americas except Canada and continental Chile
column5: and the virus will likely reach all countries and territories of the region where Aedes mosquitoes are found.How do you treat Zika?There is no treatment or vaccine for Zika infection. Companies and scientists are racing to develop a safe and effective vaccine for Zika
column6: but the World Health Organization (WHO) had said early in 2016 that it would take at least 18 months to start large-scale clinical trials of potential preventative shots.A vaccine is not expected to be ready for widespread use for at least two or three years. U.S. government researchers said they started their first clinical trial of a Zika vaccine.How dangerous is it?The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention concluded that infection with the Zika virus in pregnant women is a cause of the birth defect microcephaly and other severe brain abnormalities in babies. The CDC said now that the causal relationship has been established
column7: several important questions must still be answered with studies that could take years.According to the World Health Organization
column8: there is strong scientific consensus that Zika can cause the birth defect microcephaly in babies
column9: a condition defined by unusually small heads that can result in developmental problems. In addition
column10: the agency said it could cause Guillain-Barre syndrome
column11: a rare neurological disorder that can result in paralysis. Conclusive proof of the damage caused by Zika may take months or years.Brazil reports the number of confirmed cases of microcephaly at more than 1
column12: 700 as doctors and Brazilian health officials find that some suspected cases of microcephaly are not the disorder. Suspected ones under investigation had declined to 3
column14: 387 likely cases of the Zika virus from February until April 2.Current research in Brazil indicates the greatest microcephaly risk is associated with infection during the first trimester of pregnancy
column15: but health officials have warned an impact could be seen in later weeks. Recent studies have shown evidence of Zika in amniotic fluid

column1: What are the symptoms of Zika infection?    People infected with Zika may have a mild fever
column3: conjunctivitis
column4: muscle and joint pain and fatigue that can last for two to seven days. But as many as 80 percent of people infected never develop symptoms. The symptoms are similar to those of dengue or chikungunya
column5: which are transmitted by the same type of mosquito.How can Zika be contained?Efforts to control the spread of the virus focus on eliminating mosquito breeding sites and taking precautions against mosquito bites such as using insect repellent and mosquito nets. U.S. and international health officials have advised pregnant women to avoid travel to Latin American and Caribbean countries where they may be exposed to Zika.How widespread is the outbreak?

column1: Active Zika outbreaks have been reported in at least 54 countries or territories
column2: most of them in the Americas
column3: according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Brazil has been the country most affected. (1.usa.gov/1ovAJyh)Africa (1): Cape Verde Americas (45): Anguilla
column4: Antigua
column5: Argentina
column6: Aruba
column7: Barbados
column46: U.S. Virgin Islands and Venezuela.Oceania/Pacific Islands (8): American Samoa
column54: and Tonga. What is the history of the Zika virus?The Zika virus is found in tropical locales with large mosquito populations. Outbreaks of Zika have been recorded in Africa
column56: Southern Asia and the Western Pacific. The virus was first identified in Uganda in 1947 in rhesus monkeys and was first identified in people in 1952 in Uganda and Tanzania

column1: Can Zika be transmitted through sexual contact?The World Health Organization (WHO) said sexual transmission is ""relatively common"" and has advised pregnant women not to travel to areas with ongoing outbreaks of Zika virus. It also  advised women living in areas where the virus is being transmitted to delay getting pregnant.The U.S. CDC is investigating about a dozen cases of possible sexual transmission. Those cases involved possible transmission of the virus from men to their sex partners.But the CDC issued updated recommendations for preventing and testing for Zika infection on July 25
column2: warning that the virus can be transmitted through unprotected sex with an infected female partner.A reported case of female-to-male sexual transmission in New York City
column3: and limited human and non-human primate data indicating that Zika virus RNA can be detected in vaginal secretions
column4: led to the new warning
column5: the agency said.CDC's expanded warnings on sexual exposure to Zika now  caution against sex without a condom or other barrier method of protection with any person
column6: male or female
column7: who has traveled to or lives in an area with Zika
column8: including female to female transmission with a pregnant partner.British health officials reported Zika was found in a man's semen two months after he was infected
column9: suggesting the virus may linger in semen long after infection symptoms fade.The PAHO said Zika can be transmitted through blood
column10: but this is an infrequent transmission mechanism. There is no evidence Zika can be transmitted to babies through breast milk.The WHO has identified Zika cases in Argentina
column13: Italy and New Zealand as likely caused by sexual transmission. What other complications are associated with Zika?Zika has also been associated with other neurological disorders
column14: including serious brain and spinal cord infections. The long-term health consequences of Zika infection are unclear. Other uncertainties surround the incubation period of the virus and how Zika interacts with other viruses that are transmitted by mosquitoes
column15: such as dengue. (Compiled by the Americas Desk)"	['Costa']	[]

The following timeline charts the origin and spread of the Zika virus from its discovery nearly 70 years ago:1947: Scientists researching yellow fever in Uganda's Zika Forest identify the virus in a rhesus monkey1948: Virus recovered from Aedes africanus mosquito in Zika Forest1952: First human cases detected in Uganda and Tanzania1954: Virus found in Nigeria1960s-80s: Zika detected in mosquitoes and monkeys across equatorial Africa1969-83: Zika found in equatorial Asia

column1: NEW YORK Billionaire activist investor Carl Icahn said on CNBC on Tuesday that Donald Trump is ""right on about the economy"" and said ""the Archie Bunker of the world"" will vote for the Republican presidential candidate.Archie Bunker
column2: a fictional conservative blue-collar worker from the New York City borough of Queens
column3: was the main character in the 1970s television comedy ""All in the Family.""Icahn praised Trump's economic plan a day after the New York real estate developer unveiled it in a speech in Detroit. Trump proposed sweeping tax breaks
column4: cuts to federal regulations and a revival of the stalled Keystone XL project.Bunker has been described as the show's ""lovable bigot

column6: you know

His campaign has pulled in less than 6 percent of what Republican nominee Mitt Romney had raised from tech donors by this point in the 2012 race. But raising money for Clinton may prove difficult. While the Democrat has raised 25 times more than Trump from tech donors so far
column6: she has drawn less than half of what President Barack Obama had raised from tech employees by this point four years ago

column13: according to an analysis performed for Reuters by Crowdpac
column14: a nonpartisan political crowdfunding startup that analyzes campaign contribution data. Trump and Clinton together reported having received $3.5 million from tech workers as of June 30
column15: compared with $11 million donated to President Barack Obama and his Republican rival Mitt Romney through June 2012

column18: see: tmsnrt.rs/2b3nEuk The Trump campaign did not respond to requests for comment on this story. The Clinton campaign asked for the methodology of the Crowdpac analysis but did not comment on its findings.To quantify the tech industry's political giving
column19: Crowdpac tallied contributions of more than $200 - the Federal Election Commission's reporting threshold - from donors who listed technology companies as their employers
column20: as well as individuals who work in related roles
column21: such as software engineers and venture capitalists. Contributions to campaigns
column22: Super PACs and joint fundraising committees were included.The analysis may have missed people who work at small technology companies not yet recognized by Crowdpac
column23: as well as individuals who have given less than $200.Technology firms lobby the government on a range of issues
column24: from privacy and encryption to immigration and trade
column25: and they have a strong interest in who sits in the Oval Office. But this year
